description: Mark Wallinger creates a replica of Freud's study for the Frieze London art fair.
title: The Id and the Ego, Depicted in Color
title_page: The Id and the Ego, Depicted in Color - The New York Times
text:
When Mark Wallinger visited Sigmund Freud’s study in Hampstead, England, recently, he was struck by the dominance of the colors red and green in the décor.
Mr. Wallinger, a Turner Prize-winning British artist, had been mulling over the symbolic nature of the two colors for some time, in particular how they relate to the human psyche. In an installation he created in 2010 for the Kunstnernes Hus in Oslo, he placed objects of art in two rooms, each presided over by a hanging traffic light: one set to green, the other to red.
“They were loosely based around the unconscious and the conscious,” he said. “The red was holding something at rest for examination, and the green was this constant ebb and flow of things in motion.”
Mr. Wallinger had been looking for a concept that would help him curate an exhibition at the Frieze London art fair for Hauser & Wirth, the gallery he joined last spring.
